questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is referred by her paediatrician because her toes "point in" when she walks. The foot progression angle is negative bilaterally (left to right). What is the most likely cause of this child's in-toeing?

options.label: D
options.text: Internal rotation contracture of the hip

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Internal tibial torsion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a 2-year-old with toes pointing inwards and a negative foot progression angle, internal tibial torsion is the most likely culprit. It is a common and usually self-limiting condition.
  • ➤ In a 2-year-old with toes pointing inwards and a negative foot progression angle, internal tibial torsion is the most likely culprit.
  • ➤ It is a common and usually self-limiting condition.

questions.text: What is the first thing to be done in severely injured patient with cervical spinal fracture and unconsciousness?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cervical spine stabilization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cervical spine stabilization is the "first" action based on the idea of performing it concurrently with, or immediately before, airway assessment to minimize the risk of further spinal cord injury.
  • ➤ Cervical spine stabilization is the "first" action based on the idea of performing it concurrently with, or immediately before, airway assessment to minimize the risk of further spinal cord injury.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presenting with a cubitus varus deformity and a history of trauma 3 months back, on clinical examination, has the preserved 3-point bony relationship of the elbow. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: D. Malunited supracondylar fracture of humerus
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Malunited supracondylar fracture of humerus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A malunited supracondylar fracture of the humerus is the most common cause of cubitus varus in children. The preserved 3-point bony relationship is a key finding that differentiates it from other elbow injuries.
  • ➤ A malunited supracondylar fracture of the humerus is the most common cause of cubitus varus in children.
  • ➤ The preserved 3-point bony relationship is a key finding that differentiates it from other elbow injuries.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male after a fall in bathroom had hip fracture as seen in the pelvic X-ray below. What will be the position of the left lower limb?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Shortened, externally rotated

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A shortened and externally rotated lower limb is the most common presentation of a hip fracture in elderly individuals. This is due to the disruption of the femur and the pull of surrounding muscles.
  • ➤ A shortened and externally rotated lower limb is the most common presentation of a hip fracture in elderly individuals.
  • ➤ This is due to the disruption of the femur and the pull of surrounding muscles.

questions.text: Which type of physeal injury is seen in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Type

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type I = Straight across Type II = Above (growth plate + metaphysis) Type III = Lower (growth plate + epiphysis) Type IV = Through everything
  • ➤ Type I = Straight across
  • ➤ Type II = Above (growth plate + metaphysis)
  • ➤ Type III = Lower (growth plate + epiphysis)
  • ➤ Type IV = Through everything

questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient is presenting with pain around knee. The x-ray is showing following image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Brodies abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice in fracture neck of femur in a 40-year-old male presenting after 2 days?

options.label: B
options.text: Closed reduction and Internal fixation by cancellous screws

options.label: C
options.text: Closed reduction and Internal fixation by Austin Moore pins

questions.correct_answer: B. Closed reduction and Internal fixation by cancellous screws
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Closed reduction and Internal fixation by cancellous screws

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Closed reduction and internal fixation with cancellous screws is the preferred treatment for femoral neck fractures in younger adults. This approach aims to preserve the native hip joint and minimize the risk of complications.
  • ➤ Closed reduction and internal fixation with cancellous screws is the preferred treatment for femoral neck fractures in younger adults.
  • ➤ This approach aims to preserve the native hip joint and minimize the risk of complications.

questions.text: The image shows the result of a Trendelenburg test. Based on the finding, what is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Superior gluteal nerve injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Injury to the superior gluteal nerve is the most common neurological cause leading to pelvis drop on the contralateral side during single-leg stance i.e., positive Trendelenburg test.
  • ➤ Injury to the superior gluteal nerve is the most common neurological cause leading to pelvis drop on the contralateral side during single-leg stance i.e., positive Trendelenburg test.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding fractures of lateral condyle of humerus except:

options.label: A
options.text: Usually seen at 6-10 years of age

options.label: D
options.text: Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is seen

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Results in Gunstock deformity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lateral condyle fractures are common in children aged 6-10. They typically result in cubitus valgus, not gunstock deformity (cubitus varus). Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is a potential late complication.
  • ➤ Lateral condyle fractures are common in children aged 6-10.
  • ➤ They typically result in cubitus valgus, not gunstock deformity (cubitus varus).
  • ➤ Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is a potential late complication.

questions.text: A patient presented with Saddle anaesthesia. Bladder and bowel are normal and muscle power is normal. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Conus medullaris lesion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of saddle anaesthesia, normal bladder and bowel function, and normal muscle power strongly suggests a conus medullaris lesion. Cauda equina syndrome typically involves bladder and bowel dysfunction. L3-L4 and L4-L5 disc prolapse primarily affect other nerve roots and do not typically cause saddle anaesthesia.
  • ➤ The combination of saddle anaesthesia, normal bladder and bowel function, and normal muscle power strongly suggests a conus medullaris lesion.
  • ➤ Cauda equina syndrome typically involves bladder and bowel dysfunction.
  • ➤ L3-L4 and L4-L5 disc prolapse primarily affect other nerve roots and do not typically cause saddle anaesthesia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to OPD with history of swelling on left hand. On examination, a pea sized nodule was present. On aspiration, clear myxoid fluid was drawn and sent for cytology. What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ganglion cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hand is a common location for ganglion cysts. A pea-sized nodule is consistent with the typical presentation of a ganglion cyst. The clear, myxoid fluid is the hallmark of a ganglion cyst.
  • ➤ The hand is a common location for ganglion cysts.
  • ➤ A pea-sized nodule is consistent with the typical presentation of a ganglion cyst.
  • ➤ The clear, myxoid fluid is the hallmark of a ganglion cyst.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with hip pain and a limp. X-ray of the pelvis is given below. What does this find suggests?

options.label: D
options.text: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Slipped capital femoral epiphysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mnemonic for SCFE: "Slipped Kids Fall Easily" — SCFE occurs in obese children, typically 11–14 years old, causing hip/knee pain and limp. The shown line on the x-ray is called Klein’s line which is characteristically used for measurement of slip in SCFE.
  • ➤ Mnemonic for SCFE: "Slipped Kids Fall Easily" — SCFE occurs in obese children, typically 11–14 years old, causing hip/knee pain and limp.
  • ➤ Mnemonic for SCFE:
  • ➤ The shown line on the x-ray is called Klein’s line which is characteristically used for measurement of slip in SCFE.

questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of shoulder of a 25-year-old male who suffered a shoulder injury and now exhibits swelling around the shoulder joint. Based on the X-ray, which structure(s) is/are probable sites of injury?
questions.correct_answer: A. Both acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligament
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Both acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligament

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The X-ray indicates a significant AC joint separation, which involves disruption of both the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.
  • ➤ The X-ray indicates a significant AC joint separation, which involves disruption of both the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with progressive pain in her right shoulder, particularly with overhead activities. On examination, she has weakness in external rotation and tenderness at the greater tuberosity. What is the most appropriate management in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Conservative treatment with NSAIDs and physical therapy

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical repair of the rotator cuff

questions.correct_answer: C. Surgical repair of the rotator cuff
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Surgical repair of the rotator cuff

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While surgical repair is a viable option for rotator cuff tears, conservative treatment is the most appropriate initial management. If the patient's symptoms don't improve with conservative treatment, then surgery can be considered.
  • ➤ While surgical repair is a viable option for rotator cuff tears, conservative treatment is the most appropriate initial management.
  • ➤ If the patient's symptoms don't improve with conservative treatment, then surgery can be considered.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with multiple painless swelling on her limbs, which she has noticed since childhood. She also has skin lesions. She reports no history of trauma but has had several pathological fractures over the years. On physical examination, she has multiple soft tissue hemangiomas on her skin. Given her clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Maffucci syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of multiple enchondromas (painless swellings), multiple soft tissue hemangiomas on the skin, and a history of pathological fractures strongly points towards Maffucci syndrome.
  • ➤ The combination of multiple enchondromas (painless swellings), multiple soft tissue hemangiomas on the skin, and a history of pathological fractures strongly points towards Maffucci syndrome.
  • ➤ The combination of multiple enchondromas (painless swellings), multiple soft tissue hemangiomas on the skin, and a history of pathological fractures strongly points towards Maffucci syndrome.

questions.text: Identify traction in below image.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dunlop's traction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dunlop's traction is used for fractures of the humerus and typically involves traction applied to the forearm with the elbow flexed, often with the arm abducted.
  • ➤ Dunlop's traction is used for fractures of the humerus and typically involves traction applied to the forearm with the elbow flexed, often with the arm abducted.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the orthopaedic clinic with persistent pain and difficulty moving his left leg following a tibia fracture that occurred 6 months ago. The fracture was initially treated with casting, but the patient reports that he has not regained full function of his leg. There is no significant displacement of the bone fragments. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Delayed union

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delayed union = Healing is slow but still possible → Most likely here. Atrophic non-union = No healing, poor biological response. Hypertrophic non-union = Good biological healing, but poor mechanical stability. Pseudarthrosis = Complete failure to heal, with formation of a false joint.
  • ➤ Delayed union = Healing is slow but still possible → Most likely here.
  • ➤ Atrophic non-union = No healing, poor biological response.
  • ➤ Hypertrophic non-union = Good biological healing, but poor mechanical stability.
  • ➤ Pseudarthrosis = Complete failure to heal, with formation of a false joint.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after falling off his bicycle. He complains of pain and swelling in his distal radius. The pain is localized to the area around the wrist, and he is unable to move his hand without significant discomfort. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Salter-Harris Type II fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which method of scoliosis has been depicted in the image given below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cobb’s angle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image shows the Cobb’s angle, which is used for the measurement of degree of lateral curvature of the spine in scoliosis.
  • ➤ The given image shows the Cobb’s angle, which is used for the measurement of degree of lateral curvature of the spine in scoliosis.

questions.text: Hyperextension at MCP joint and flexion at IP joint occurs due to involvement of which muscle?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lumbricals and interossei

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperextension of the MCP joint and flexion of the IP joint is seen in the claw hand deformity due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand i.e., the lumbricals and the interossei.
  • ➤ Hyperextension of the MCP joint and flexion of the IP joint is seen in the claw hand deformity due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand i.e., the lumbricals and the interossei.

questions.text: Risk factor(s) for Legg-calve-Perthe’s disease is/are: Accelerated skeletal growth Growth hormone abnormalities Positive family history Female sex Passive smoking
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 3, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The risk factors associated with Legg-Calve-Perthe’s disease are a positive family history & presence of passive smoking.
  • ➤ The risk factors associated with Legg-Calve-Perthe’s disease are a positive family history & presence of passive smoking.

questions.text: What is the principle of TENS which is used for alleviating pain around joints and nerve pain?
questions.correct_answer: A. Gate theory of pain control
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gate theory of pain control

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The TENS modality alleviates the neurogenic pain by the principle of pain gate mechanism.
  • ➤ The TENS modality alleviates the neurogenic pain by the principle of pain gate mechanism.

questions.text: Salt pepper skull is a feature of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Primary hyperparathyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Salt and pepper skull is a radiographic feature of primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • ➤ Salt and pepper skull is a radiographic feature of primary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He complains of neck pain but is alert and hemodynamically stable. His x-ray image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hangman's fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Following changes are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) OA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given X-ray shows Heberden’s nodes and Bouchard’s nodes in the hand, which are classical of osteoarthritis. DIP involvement is seen. There is subchondral sclerosis at the PIP and DIP joints along with osteophytes. The MCP joint is spared in OA.
  • ➤ The given X-ray shows Heberden’s nodes and Bouchard’s nodes in the hand, which are classical of osteoarthritis.
  • ➤ DIP involvement is seen.
  • ➤ There is subchondral sclerosis at the PIP and DIP joints along with osteophytes.
  • ➤ The MCP joint is spared in OA.

questions.text: Tube cast is applied for injuries of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Knee Joint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tube cast or patellar tendon bearing cast is used for the fractures around the knee like fracture of patella, fracture of middle third shaft of tibia.
  • ➤ Tube cast or patellar tendon bearing cast is used for the fractures around the knee like fracture of patella, fracture of middle third shaft of tibia.

questions.text: Seat belt injury is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chance fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Seat belt injury is chance fracture of the thoracolumbar junction.
  • ➤ Seat belt injury is chance fracture of the thoracolumbar junction.

questions.text: A patient with open wound with fracture of both bones of right lower limb came to the emergency. The doctor labelled the injury as 3B according to Gustilo-Anderson Classification. Which of the following would represent the injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Open wound with fracture with wound <1 cm

options.label: B
options.text: Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury

options.label: C
options.text: Open wound >10 cm, though soft tissue coverage not required

options.label: D
options.text: Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

questions.correct_answer: D. Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The type 3B of the open fracture involves significant periosteal stripping and it requires secondary bone coverage procedure like skin grafting or flap. The wound size is > 10cm in this type.
  • ➤ The type 3B of the open fracture involves significant periosteal stripping and it requires secondary bone coverage procedure like skin grafting or flap.
  • ➤ The wound size is > 10cm in this type.

questions.text: What is the type of fracture shown in the X-ray of left shoulder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neer classification grade 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image shows the fracture of the proximal humerus. The type of fracture according to Neer’s classification is grade 4 involving fracture of all 4 parts of the joint.
  • ➤ The given image shows the fracture of the proximal humerus.
  • ➤ The type of fracture according to Neer’s classification is grade 4 involving fracture of all 4 parts of the joint.

questions.text: A patient developed breathlessness and chest pain on second postoperative after a total hip replacement. Echocardiography showed right ventricular dilatation and tricuspid regurgitation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pulmonary embolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pulmonary embolism occurs when a blood clot, usually originating from the legs (deep vein thrombosis), travels to the lungs and blocks a pulmonary artery. Symptoms can include sudden onset of breathlessness, chest pain, and in severe cases, right heart strain as evidenced by right ventricular dilatation and tricuspid regurgitation on echocardiography. This is seen as a common complication of total hip replacement surgeries.
  • ➤ Pulmonary embolism occurs when a blood clot, usually originating from the legs (deep vein thrombosis), travels to the lungs and blocks a pulmonary artery.
  • ➤ Symptoms can include sudden onset of breathlessness, chest pain, and in severe cases, right heart strain as evidenced by right ventricular dilatation and tricuspid regurgitation on echocardiography.
  • ➤ This is seen as a common complication of total hip replacement surgeries.

questions.text: The most common nerve involved in posterior dislocation of elbow is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ulnar nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most commonly injured nerve in posterior dislocation of elbow is the ulnar nerve.
  • ➤ The most commonly injured nerve in posterior dislocation of elbow is the ulnar nerve.

questions.text: Earliest way to detect development of compartment syndrome by a nurse in a patient with cast is:

options.label: A
options.text: Check radial pulse by displacing the cast

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Decreased response to analgesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The earliest way to detect compartment syndrome in a patient is a decreased response to the analgesics. The patient will complaint of no reduction in the pain symptoms.
  • ➤ The earliest way to detect compartment syndrome in a patient is a decreased response to the analgesics.
  • ➤ The patient will complaint of no reduction in the pain symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding osteoid osteoma?

options.label: A
options.text: The femur and tibia are the commonest bones involved

options.label: B
options.text: Radiologically appears as a radiolucent lesion surrounded by dense bone

options.label: C
options.text: It is a benign bone tumour, presents with severe pain that is typically relieved by aspirin

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteoid osteoma is a benign bone tumor that presents with severe pain , which is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications. The femur and tibia are the most commonly involved bones. Radiologically, it appears as a radiolucent lesion surrounded by dense bone.
  • ➤ Osteoid osteoma is a benign bone tumor that presents with severe pain , which is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications.
  • ➤ benign
  • ➤ severe pain
  • ➤ The femur and tibia are the most commonly involved bones.
  • ➤ femur
  • ➤ tibia
  • ➤ Radiologically, it appears as a radiolucent lesion surrounded by dense bone.
  • ➤ radiolucent

questions.text: A 75-year-female has chronic backache. X-ray spine is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Osteoporosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image shows codfish vertebra, which is diagnostic of osteoporosis. Codfish vertebrae are seen due to compression fracture of the spine.
  • ➤ The given image shows codfish vertebra, which is diagnostic of osteoporosis.
  • ➤ Codfish vertebrae are seen due to compression fracture of the spine.

questions.text: March fracture involves:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2nd and 3rd metatarsal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ March fracture involves stress fracture of the 2 nd and 3 rd metatarsal neck (2 nd MT > 3 rd MT).
  • ➤ March fracture involves stress fracture of the 2 nd and 3 rd metatarsal neck (2 nd MT > 3 rd MT).

questions.text: The earliest radiological sign in Pott’s disease is:
questions.correct_answer: C. Narrowing of intervertebral disc space
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Narrowing of intervertebral disc space.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The earliest radiological sign seen in Pott’s spine is the narrowing of the intervertebral disc space and loss of curvature of the spine due to paravertebral muscle spasm.
  • ➤ The earliest radiological sign seen in Pott’s spine is the narrowing of the intervertebral disc space and loss of curvature of the spine due to paravertebral muscle spasm.

questions.text: X-ray proximal femur in a patient with pain hip is given below. The deformity shown is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Shepherd crook deformity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image in the question shows the s hepherd crook deformity of the proximal femur , seen in case of fibrous dysplasia of the bone.
  • ➤ The given image in the question shows the s hepherd crook deformity of the proximal femur , seen in case of fibrous dysplasia of the bone.
  • ➤ hepherd crook deformity of the proximal femur
  • ➤ fibrous dysplasia

questions.text: A 74-year-old man presented with low back pain that was radiating to his legs. On examination of the spine, a palpable step was felt in the lumbosacral region. The X-ray of the spine is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Spondylolisthesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ On examination of the spine, a palpable step felt in the lumbosacral region is the classical sign of spondylolisthesis, which is the forward slippage of one vertebra over the other.
  • ➤ On examination of the spine, a palpable step felt in the lumbosacral region is the classical sign of spondylolisthesis, which is the forward slippage of one vertebra over the other.

questions.text: A patient has a painless, palpable bony mass near the metaphysis of a long bone. X-ray done is shown below. What seems to be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Osteochondroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A painless, palpable bony mass near the metaphysis of a long bone is seen in osteochondroma which is a developmental malformation and not a true neoplasm. It originates from the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodule. Most of these lesions cause no symptoms and are incidental findings.
  • ➤ A painless, palpable bony mass near the metaphysis of a long bone is seen in osteochondroma which is a developmental malformation and not a true neoplasm.
  • ➤ It originates from the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodule.
  • ➤ Most of these lesions cause no symptoms and are incidental findings.

questions.text: What is the type of splint shown in the image called as?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cock-up splint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The image shown in the question is of a cock up splint which is used in cases of wrist drop due to radial nerve injury.
  • ➤ The image shown in the question is of a cock up splint which is used in cases of wrist drop due to radial nerve injury.

questions.text: A boy presented with multiple non-suppurative osteomyelitis with sickle cell anemia. What will be the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Salmonella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multiple, non-suppurative osteomyelitis with sickle cell anemia is most commonly caused by salmonella species.
  • ➤ Multiple, non-suppurative osteomyelitis with sickle cell anemia is most commonly caused by salmonella species.

questions.text: Wimberger ring sign is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Scurvy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wimberger’s ring sign is a radiographic feature of scurvy.
  • ➤ Wimberger’s ring sign is a radiographic feature of scurvy.

questions.text: X-ray of a 10-year-old child is shown. Which of the following is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior pad of fat sign present

options.label: D
options.text: Supracondylar humerus fracture can raise anterior fat pad

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fracture of radius head

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ In a child with elbow trauma, always think of supracondylar humerus fracture first — not radial head fracture

questions.text: Foot drop is due to palsy of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Deep peroneal nerve

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Foot drop is caused due to injury to the deep peroneal nerve, a branch of the common peroneal nerve.
  • ➤ Foot drop is caused due to injury to the deep peroneal nerve, a branch of the common peroneal nerve.

questions.text: First to appear amongst the ossification centres about the elbow is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Capitellum

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Capitellum is the first bone to appear among the ossification centres about the elbow.
  • ➤ Capitellum is the first bone to appear among the ossification centres about the elbow.

questions.text: Fat embolism syndrome is most commonly seen after:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Femur fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fat embolism syndrome is most commonly seen after the fracture of the femur if not stabilized within first 48-72 hours.
  • ➤ Fat embolism syndrome is most commonly seen after the fracture of the femur if not stabilized within first 48-72 hours.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for fracture shaft femur in a child less than 2 years of age is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hip spica

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For the treatment of femoral shaft fracture in children < 2 years of age is hip spica cast.

questions.text: Shown below is an X-ray of a patient with history of a chronic knee pain. True statement concerning the X-ray shown would be:

options.label: D
options.text: Bipartite patella; X-ray of other knee

questions.correct_answer: D. Bipartite patella; X-ray of other knee
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bipartite patella; X-ray of other knee

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which type of amputation is shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Below knee amputation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is true about DDH?

options.label: B
options.text: Limbs are in adduction, internal rotation and flexion in old children

questions.correct_answer: B. Limbs are in adduction, internal rotation and flexion in old children
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Limbs are in adduction, internal rotation and flexion in old children

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DDH is commonly seen in female patients. The limbs are in adduction, internal rotation & flexed position in older children. Femoral neck is anteverted. Ligamentum teres is thickened & elongated.
  • ➤ DDH is commonly seen in female patients.
  • ➤ The limbs are in adduction, internal rotation & flexed position in older children.
  • ➤ Femoral neck is anteverted.
  • ➤ Ligamentum teres is thickened & elongated.
